articles.headline: In Harsh Rebuke, Appeals Court Rejects Trump’s Election Challenge in Pennsylvania
articles.snippet: “Voters, not lawyers, choose the president,” a judge for the Third Circuit Court of Appeals wrote in the 21-page repudiation of Mr. Trump’s legal effort to halt Pennsylvania’s certification process.
articles.abstract: “Voters, not lawyers, choose the president,” a judge for the Third Circuit Court of Appeals wrote in the 21-page repudiation of Mr. Trump’s legal effort to halt Pennsylvania’s certification process.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a blistering decision, a Philadelphia appeals court ruled on Friday that the Trump campaign could not stop — or attempt to reverse — the certification of the voting results in Pennsylvania, reprimanding the president’s team by noting that “calling an election unfair does not make it so.”

articles.headline: For the World Economy, a Grim Slog Tempered by New Hopes
articles.snippet: The emergence of vaccines has taken the edge off the worst fears, but a meaningful economic recovery probably remains distant.
articles.abstract: The emergence of vaccines has taken the edge off the worst fears, but a meaningful economic recovery probably remains distant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly a year into a pandemic that has ravaged the global economy like no time since the Great Depression, the only clear pathway toward improved fortunes is containing the virus itself.

articles.headline: Gunmen Assassinate Iran’s Top Nuclear Scientist in Ambush, Provoking New Crisis
articles.snippet: Iran expressed fury over the killing of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, blaming it on Israel and the United States. His death may complicate President-elect Biden’s intention to restore the Iranian nuclear deal.
articles.abstract: Iran expressed fury over the killing of Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, blaming it on Israel and the United States. His death may complicate President-elect Biden’s intention to restore the Iranian nuclear deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iran’s top nuclear scientist, long identified by American and Israeli intelligence as the guiding figure behind a covert effort to design an atomic warhead, was shot and killed Friday in what the Iranian media called a roadside ambush as he and his bodyguards traveled outside Tehran.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: How Democrats Suffered Crushing Down-Ballot Losses Across America
articles.snippet: In statehouse races, suburban voters’ disgust with President Trump failed to translate into a rebuke of other Republicans, ensuring the party’s grip on partisan mapmaking.
articles.abstract: In statehouse races, suburban voters’ disgust with President Trump failed to translate into a rebuke of other Republicans, ensuring the party’s grip on partisan mapmaking.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEXFORD, Pa. — Just a few seats shy of a majority in the State House of Representatives, Democrats in Pennsylvania this year zeroed in on Republican-held suburban districts, where disdain for President Trump ran hot.

articles.headline: Pedophile Scandal Can’t Crack the Closed Circles of Literary France
articles.snippet: The scandal surrounding the writer Gabriel Matzneff was not limited to his pedophilia. It also opened a window on the entrenched and clubby nature of many of France’s elite institutions.
articles.abstract: The scandal surrounding the writer Gabriel Matzneff was not limited to his pedophilia. It also opened a window on the entrenched and clubby nature of many of France’s elite institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — One of France’s most prestigious literary awards, the Renaudot can change a writer’s career overnight. Prizewinners jump onto best-seller lists. Publishers earn bragging rights in a nation that places literature at the heart of its sense of grandeur and global standing.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut

articles.headline: Plastic Dividers and Masks All Day: What Teaching in a Pandemic Looks Like
articles.snippet: As school districts diverge on handling the pandemic, Baltimore City Public Schools are slowly trying to get students back in the classroom. It has not been easy, but neither has remote learning.
articles.abstract: As school districts diverge on handling the pandemic, Baltimore City Public Schools are slowly trying to get students back in the classroom. It has not been easy, but neither has remote learning.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Zia Hellman prepared to welcome her kindergarten students back to Walter P. Carter Elementary/Middle School this month the way any teacher would on the first day of school: She fussed over her classroom.

articles.headline: Biden Aides’ Ties to Consulting and Investment Firms Pose Ethics Test
articles.snippet: Some of the president-elect’s choices for top posts have done work for undisclosed corporate clients and aided a fund that invests in government contractors.
articles.abstract: Some of the president-elect’s choices for top posts have done work for undisclosed corporate clients and aided a fund that invests in government contractors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One firm helps companies navigate global risks and the political and procedural ins and outs of Washington. The other is an investment fund with a particular interest in military contractors.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: Assassination in Iran Could Limit Biden’s Options. Was That the Goal?
articles.snippet: The killing of Iran’s top nuclear scientist is likely to impede the country’s military ambitions. Its real purpose may have been to prevent the president-elect from resuming diplomacy with Tehran.
articles.abstract: The killing of Iran’s top nuclear scientist is likely to impede the country’s military ambitions. Its real purpose may have been to prevent the president-elect from resuming diplomacy with Tehran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The assassination of the scientist who led Iran’s pursuit of a nuclear weapon for the past two decades threatens to cripple President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s effort to revive the Iran nuclear deal before he can even begin his diplomacy with Tehran.

articles.headline: Virus Deaths Approach Spring Record Amid Changing U.S. Crisis
articles.snippet: On April 15, more Americans were reported dead of Covid-19 than on any other day of the pandemic. The daily toll is growing close once more.
articles.abstract: On April 15, more Americans were reported dead of Covid-19 than on any other day of the pandemic. The daily toll is growing close once more.
articles.lead_paragraph: On April 15, the United States reached a grim nadir in the pandemic: 2,752 people across the country were reported to have died from Covid-19 that Wednesday, more than on any day before or since.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, Joseph Goldstein and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: In Key States, Republicans Were Critical in Resisting Trump’s Election Narrative
articles.snippet: They refuted conspiracy theories, certified results, dismissed lawsuits and repudiated a president of their own party.
articles.abstract: They refuted conspiracy theories, certified results, dismissed lawsuits and repudiated a president of their own party.
articles.lead_paragraph: The telephone call would have been laugh-out-loud ridiculous if it had not been so serious. When Tina Barton picked up, she found someone from President Trump’s campaign asking her to sign a letter raising doubts about the results of the election.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Kathleen Gray

articles.headline: A Rush to Expand the Border Wall That Many Fear Is Here to Stay
articles.snippet: Despite the president-elect’s vow to halt the project, the Trump administration is expanding the wall at a breakneck pace.
articles.abstract: Despite the president-elect’s vow to halt the project, the Trump administration is expanding the wall at a breakneck pace.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOUGLAS, Ariz. — Four years ago, President Trump took office with a pledge to build a towering wall on America’s border with Mexico — a symbol of his determination to halt immigration from countries to the south and build a barrier that would long outlast him.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Adriana Zehbrauskas

articles.headline: Brazen Killings Expose Iran’s Vulnerabilities as It Struggles to Respond
articles.snippet: After suffering a string of audacious attacks, Tehran faces an agonizing choice: embracing hard-liner demands for swift retaliation or trying to make a fresh start with the Biden administration.
articles.abstract: After suffering a string of audacious attacks, Tehran faces an agonizing choice: embracing hard-liner demands for swift retaliation or trying to make a fresh start with the Biden administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: The raid alone was brazen enough. A team of Israeli commandos with high-powered torches blasted their way into a vault of a heavily guarded warehouse deep in Iran and made off before dawn with 5,000 pages of top secret papers on the country’s nuclear program.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Ronen Bergman and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: The Lost Days That Made Bergamo a Coronavirus Tragedy
articles.snippet: The northern Italian province became one of the deadliest killing fields for the virus in the Western world. But a Times investigation found that faulty guidance and bureaucratic delays rendered the toll far worse than it had to be.
articles.abstract: The northern Italian province became one of the deadliest killing fields for the virus in the Western world. But a Times investigation found that faulty guidance and bureaucratic delays rendered the toll far worse than it had to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERGAMO, Italy — When Franco Orlandi, a usually hale former truck driver, arrived in mid-February with a cough and fever at an emergency room in the northern Italian province of Bergamo, doctors determined that he had a flu and sent him home. Two days later, an ambulance brought the 83-year-old back. He couldn’t breathe.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Fabio Bucciarelli

articles.headline: Nike and Coca-Cola Lobby Against Xinjiang Forced Labor Bill
articles.snippet: Business groups and major companies like Apple have been pressing Congress to alter legislation cracking down on imports of goods made with forced labor from persecuted Muslim minorities in China.
articles.abstract: Business groups and major companies like Apple have been pressing Congress to alter legislation cracking down on imports of goods made with forced labor from persecuted Muslim minorities in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nike and Coca-Cola are among the major companies and business groups lobbying Congress to weaken a bill that would ban imported goods made with forced labor in China’s Xinjiang region, according to congressional staff members and other people familiar with the matter, as well as lobbying records that show vast spending on the legislation.

articles.headline: One Seat, Competing Pressures as Newsom Considers Senate Pick
articles.snippet: Alex Padilla, California’s secretary of state, has emerged as the front-runner to succeed Kamala Harris. But Gov. Gavin Newsom appears to be in no rush to make his choice.
articles.abstract: Alex Padilla, California’s secretary of state, has emerged as the front-runner to succeed Kamala Harris. But Gov. Gavin Newsom appears to be in no rush to make his choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Since Gavin Newsom’s days as a young upstart running for mayor of San Francisco through more than two decades of public life, Alex Padilla has been a stalwart ally.
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: The Luxury E-Commerce Wars Heat Up
articles.snippet: On one side: Amazon. On the other: a new alliance of brands and platforms. Who will win?
articles.abstract: On one side: Amazon. On the other: a new alliance of brands and platforms. Who will win?
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2015, the chairman and controlling shareholder of the luxury goods group Richemont, Johann Rupert, took to the stage at an industry conference in Monte Carlo and issued a rallying cry to some of his biggest rivals.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Paton and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: The King of Trump TV Thinks You’re Dumb Enough to Buy It
articles.snippet: Chris Ruddy, the C.E.O. of Newsmax, has found a business opportunity in feeding Trump supporters the fantasy that the president could still win the election.
articles.abstract: Chris Ruddy, the C.E.O. of Newsmax, has found a business opportunity in feeding Trump supporters the fantasy that the president could still win the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2004, Hillary Clinton was in the Senate and Christopher Ruddy had some making up to do. He was, back then, best known as “the Inspector Clouseau” of the Vince Foster case — a New York Post reporter who had popularized the baseless theory that Mrs. Clinton’s friend, who committed suicide in 1993, had been murdered.
